awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Leakage of Communications Signatures: Analysis of Eavesdropping Attacks and Proactive Countermeasures
awd_abstract_narration:
As society continues to depend on the rapidly expanding wireless ecosystem, we are challenged with serious threats related to user privacy, data confidentiality, and critical system availability. A significant portion of these threats is attributed to the broadcast nature of wireless transmissions. Using commodity radio hardware, unauthorized parties can easily eavesdrop on over-the-air transmissions and breach the privacy of communicating users by tracking their whereabouts and movements, and inferring their associations, health state, and preferences. Common (application-level) cryptographic mechanisms fail to provide adequate security and privacy, as they leave low-level transmission identifiers open to traffic analysis. 

This project focuses on designing and evaluating privacy-preserving communication methods for mitigating information leakage due to eavesdropping. Novel physical-layer obfuscation techniques that carefully control intentional interference from transmitters and/or receivers are being designed to prevent traffic analysis at the frame level. The goal of these techniques is to render packets (including their unencrypted headers) undecodable by any unauthorized party. These physical-layer techniques are augmented with traffic normalization mechanisms at the flow level, whose objective is to hide complex network and traffic features, such as device role, routing paths, etc. Colluding eavesdroppers who monitor the system for long periods of time are also being investigated. The outcomes of this project are expected to have profound impacts on the security, privacy, and usability of a wide range of critical systems that rely on wireless technologies, including transportation and aviation networks, mobile computing platforms, e-commerce, critical national infrastructures, medical systems, and others.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed at designing and evaluating privacy-preserving communication methods for mitigating the leakage of information to adversarial eavesdroppers in a wireless network. The developed methods addressed different time scales of eavesdropping. At the fine time scale (e.g., packet duration), novel Physical-layer mechanisms that provide secret and signature-free packet transmissions were introduced.  Some of these mechanisms exploit self-interference suppression along with friendly jamming (a.k.a. artificial noise) techniques to achieve location-independent secret communications. In this novel friendly jamming framework, both the legitimate transmitter and receiver inject artificial noise into the communication channel to render the legitimate signal undecodable at malicious eavesdroppers. Only the intended receiver, who is aware of the jamming signal, can suppress the intentional interference and decode the communications. A series of novel methods relying on MIMO precoding were designed to allow the confidential reception at the intended receivers while maintaining high levels of signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio at all eavesdropper locations. The secrecy rate of the communications was analytically evaluated for various scenarios. A notable feature of our approach was that receiver-based friendly jamming degraded the eavesdropping capabilities at the eavesdroppers, even when the latter observed correlated channels to the intended receivers.

The project further characterized vulnerabilities of massive MIMO systems against active attackers. Massive MIMO systems often operate in a time-division duplexing (TDD) fashion, where uplink and downlink transmissions alternate in time over the same frequency channel. The base station (BS) estimates the channel state information (CSI) at mobile users based on the quality of uplink pilot transmissions. Downlink transmission rates are highly dependent on these estimates, as the precoding at the BS requires the CSI. However, an attacker can contaminate the uplink pilot sequences by generating identical pilots to those of users. The PIs considered a single-cell multiuser massive MIMO network in the presence of an attacker and studied an attack model in which the attacker aims at minimizing the sum-rate of downlink transmissions by contaminating uplink pilot transmissions. Downlink transmission rates were derived in the presence and absence of the pilot contamination (PC) attack, exploiting the channel hardening effect (vanishing of small-scale fading as the number of antennas tends to inﬁnity) in massive MIMO to analyze the attack strategies. Optimal attack strategies were investigated for two cases: when the attacker knows the locations of the BS and of the users, and when these locations are unknown. Considering a ﬁxed power allocation strategy at the BS for downlink information signals) convex problems were formulated for the optimal PC attack. Further, we studied an attack model where the attacker generates jamming signals in both the pilot and downlink data transmission phases (hybrid attack). For this attack, the attacker is required to have a full-duplex radio. Stochastic optimization techniques were used to ﬁnd the optimal power allocation at the attacker that minimize the downlink sum-rate of the system.

For longer time-scale and/or colluding eavesdroppers, the PIs showed that the adversary can exploit very simple transmission semantics, such as the time of transmission and frame duration to infer contextual information of interest. We constructed network subgraphs with special coverage characteristics to obfuscate the traffic patterns within a network and hide transmission attributes such as the time of an event, its geographic position, and the event type. We characterized the related tradeoffs in privacy level, communication overhead, and delay.

Other aspects of the project included the development of PHY-layer voting mechanisms for enabling over-the-air-coordination of a group of agents in a fast and secure manner, the construction of secure pairing methods between devices that do not pre-share any secrets, the integrity verification of navigation signals using hard-to-forge physical phenomena such as the Doppler shift, and the efficient obfuscation of plaintext fields used in protocol coordination.

The project fulfilled several educational and outreach objectives. It provided opportunities for training and professional development to several Ph.D. and M.S. students (three of the students were females). One student supported in part by this project joined academia as a tenure-track faculty, whereas another became a postdoctoral researcher. The rest of the students have assumed positions in leading industry companies. Moreover, results from this project have been integrated into the curricula of undergraduate and graduate courses. 

The project has resulted in six Ph.D. dissertations, two M.S. theses, over 30 peer-reviewed publications in top international conferences and high-impact journals, and two granted patents. The project results have been broadly disseminated through these publications and also via numerous presentations in conferences, research colloquia, and university seminars.
